svg.text: Johannesburg as Exemplar for African Urban Health Research
Environmental Burden of Disease in African urban settings - Methodological innovations for data-scarce contexts

g.text: JOHANNESBURG: KEY STATISTICS FOR AFRICAN URBAN HEALTH RESEARCH
KEY REFERENCES: AFRICAN URBAN HEALTH CONTEXT
• UN-Habitat. (2020). The state of African cities 2018: The geography of African investment. United Nations.
• Parnell, S., & Pieterse, E. (2014). Africa's urban revolution. Zed Books.
• Pillay-van Wyk, V., et al. (2016). Mortality trends in South Africa 1997-2012. Lancet Global Health, 4(9), e642-e653.
• Mayosi, B. M., et al. (2009). The burden of non-communicable diseases in South Africa. Lancet, 374(9693), 934-947.
• Engelbrecht, F., et al. (2015). Projections of rapidly rising surface temperatures over Africa. Environmental Research Letters, 10(8).
• IPCC. (2022). Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Working Group II Contribution to AR6.
TRANSFERABLE METHODOLOGY: FUTURE AFRICAN CITY APPLICATIONS
Cairo, Egypt | Lagos, Nigeria | Nairobi, Kenya | Accra, Ghana
Multi-city comparative analysis • Climate adaptation planning • Health system strengthening
Framework for LMICs with limited data resources

svg.text: African Urban Context Framework | ENBEL Conference 2025
Johannesburg as Exemplar for Environmental Health Research in African Cities
